responses.text: Uh... not sure, but I'm going to go with 'not much.'
Ew, a talking bug.
Whatever's necessary, I suppose.
That depends. Are you the xenobiologist who's supposed to study me?

0.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
0.text: Go ahead and take a seat on the exam table over there. One question before we begin - in your culture, how much clothing is permissible to remove in front of a medical professional?

responses.text: I guess this is the part where I tell you I have amnesia.
I haven't come up with a name yet, but I'm working on it.
I don't know. I lost all my memories up to a few hours ago.

1.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
1.text: Well, in the interest of cultural sensitivity, I'll allow you to keep your undergarments on. If your species wears undergarments. What do you call yourselves, by the way?

responses.text: Sorry. I just don't like bugs.
If I had known there were bug people, I would have stayed home.
I'm very sorry. It was just a reaction.

2.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
2.text: Oh, like I haven't heard that one before. Rudeness aside, I'm a Sprite. By your reaction, I must be the first one you've seen on the station. Congratulations on your introduction to the fascinating biodiversity of the galaxy.

responses.text: I guess this is the part where I tell you I have amnesia.
I can only speak for my own sense of physical modesty, I'm afraid.
I don't know. I lost all my memories up to a few hours ago.

3.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
3.text: What a refreshingly practical attitude. Either that, or your species lacks a sense of physical modesty, and those clothes are just for aesthetic appeal. Not that it matters for the purposes of my examination, but out of healthy scientific curiosity, which is it?

responses.text: I guess this is the part where I tell you I have amnesia.
I'm afraid I can't tell you much about my culture.
I don't know. I lost all my memories up to a few hours ago.

4.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
4.text: Indeed! Very astute. This will be a physical examination, so some removal of your clothing will be necessary. Given the diversity of intelligent life aboard the station, I do my best to observe a certain level of cultural sensitivity. Hence the question.

responses.text: Valken? Who's that?
You sound pleased about making his life harder.
Why is my amnesia such a problem for him?

5.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
5.text: You've lost your memories? Oh, Valken is going to hate that. I look forward to seeing him tackle such an enormous obstacle to his work.

responses.text: Unable. I have amnesia.
I've lost all my memories up to a few hours ago.
How about both? Amnesia, plus generally obstinate.

6.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
6.text: What do you mean? Surely it's a simple question. Are you unable or unwilling to answer?

responses.text: It's fine with me, but I can't speak for my species. I have amnesia.
I'm going to go with 'as little as possible.'
Whatever's necessary for the exam.

7.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
7.text: Hopefully you can put your prejudices aside for the length of the examination. Now, I'd like to return to my previous question. How much clothing are you willing to remove for this exam? I like to be culturally sensitive, but some removal will be necessary.

responses.text: I'm not large. You're just small.
I guess that's another perspective.
Is everything on your planet small?

8.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
8.text: It's... all right. You certainly aren't the first to have reacted that way. Trust me, when my race first made contact with the rest of the galaxy, we were surprised to discover that intelligent life tends to evolve in such... largeness.

responses.text: Does that mean I won't pass his exam?
He'll just have to do his best.
I could make some stuff up.

9.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
9.text: Dr. Valken, my colleague. He specializes in alien psychology. I focus on the physical, so your amnesia doesn't affect my work much. But you're going to have a very hard time answering Valken's questions about your species' history and cultural practices.

responses.text: Does that mean I won't pass his exam?
He'll just have to do his best.
I could make some stuff up.

10.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
10.text: Dr. Valken is my colleague and I respect him very much. We simply take very different approaches to the task of learning about alien species, and it's always a little vindicating when my approach is indisputably more successful. As it will likely be in this case, given that his psychological profile on you is bound to be incomplete.

responses.text: Does that mean I won't pass his exam?
He'll just have to do his best.
I could make some stuff up.

11.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
11.text: My colleague, Dr. Valken, specializes in alien psychology. We were both told to examine you and report on whether your species poses a threat to any other races on the station. Valken will have a very difficult time proving that you aren't dangerous if you can't answer any of his questions.

responses.text: Of course.
Fine.
I'll consider that a concession.

12.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
12.text: That argument will get us nowhere. You need a positive report from me to pass quarantine, correct? I suggest we continue with the exam.

responses.text: END

13.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
13.text: Double-click this passage to edit it.

responses.text: Of course.
It is fascinating, though.
I came here to get an exam, not listen to a lecture.

14.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
14.text: No, many of the dumb, lumbering beasts are quite large. On our planet, brain size isn't an indicator for intelligence. On most others, it is. Just one of the many fascinating differences that sparked my interest in xenobiology. But we'll have to save this discussion for another time.

responses.text: It's fine with me, but I can't speak for my species. I have amnesia.
I'm going to go with 'as little as possible.'
Whatever's necessary for the exam.

15.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
15.text: Now, I'd like to return to my previous question. How much clothing are you willing to remove for this exam? I like to be culturally sensitive, but some removal will be necessary.

responses.text: Sure. Go ahead.
I'm as curious as you are.
The sooner I pass these exams, the better.

16.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
16.text: I don't know. Even if you have no memories, Dr. Valken likely has some way of ascertaining whether you could be prone to violence. Now, shall we proceed with the physical exam?

responses.text: Sure. Go ahead.
I'm as curious as you are.
The sooner I pass these exams, the better.

17.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
17.text: Dr. Valken is an excellent scientist. I'm sure he'll be up to the challenge. Now, shall we proceed with the physical exam?

responses.text: Sure. Go ahead.
I'm as curious as you are.
The sooner I pass these exams, the better.

18.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
18.text: I would advise against it. Dr. Valken has a very keen sense for deception. It's an important skill in his profession. Now, shall we proceed with the physical exam?

responses.text: Do you always say everything you're thinking out loud?

19.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
19.text: Well, you're obviously a biped. Your bone structure resembles that of an Asura... there are differences, of course, but the overall similarity is strong. That suggests similar evolutionary pressures. No tail, suggesting a better sense of balance than the Asura.

20.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
20.text: Be patient. I don't like fidgety patients. Let me start the recorder... Now I'll begin.

responses.text: Fair enough.

21.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
21.text: When I'm recording a first exam of a heretofore unknown species for entry into medical records? Yes. I do.

responses.text: No. That was there when I woke up with no memories.
Whoever rescued me from my planet must have done it.

22.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
22.text: No scars or markings on the body... except for this laceration on your scalp. Someone seems to have cleaned the area and stitched the epidermis back together. Did you do this yourself?

responses.text: Stitching up my own head? No thanks.
I guess I could have been a doctor. There's no way of knowing.
You're probably right. I wish I knew who did it.

23.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
23.text: Interesting. It's possible that you could have done it before losing your memories, although from what I can tell of your physiology, a great deal of finesse would be required to perform such a procedure on yourself without assistance.

responses.text: It hurt when I woke up, but it feels better now.
How would I know if I had an infection?
Yes, let's leave it alone for now.

24.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
24.text: Well, they knew what they were doing. These stitches are very clean, and the wound appears free from infection. I can't be sure, of course, given how little I know of your immune system, but I would rather leave it alone than risk reopening the wound.

responses.text: It might.
Maybe when it heals, I'll get my memories back.
Who cares? Get on with the exam already.

25.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
25.text: It looks like the wound was caused by a sharp object, but there's very little tearing. It's a good thing it didn't do more damage, but I wonder whether it has anything to do with your amnesia.

responses.text: That should be interesting.
Hmph. What does he know?

26.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
26.text: Indeed. You could have been a doctor, or perhaps even a biologist. Dr. Valken may be able to determine whether you are psychologically suited for those professions.

responses.text: That's good.
I hope not. An infection would probably make it very hard to get out of quarantine.

27.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
27.text: It's difficult to say, but if your immune system is similar to an Asura's, you'll probably run a fever. The area would likely become inflamed. It would be good to keep an eye on it, but it doesn't look like an infection risk.

responses.text: Fine, let's get this over with.
Extraction? That doesn't sound pleasant.

28.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
28.text: I'll need samples of most of your bodily fluids for testing. Let's extract those now. We need to make sure they don't contain any harmful compounds.

responses.text: That's too bad.
Well, I can always hope for the best.

29.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
29.text: That would be very fortunate, indeed. However, the brain rarely heals as quickly as injury to the tissue surrounding it. If your amnesia resulted from damage to the brain, I would expect a lengthy recovery time.

responses.text: What is it?
I thought the psychologist was supposed to ask the questions.

30.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
30.text: ... Your cooperation is appreciated. I'll start a machine analysis of these samples. In the meantime, I have another question for you.

responses.text: Fine, I'll do it.
This better not hurt.

31.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
31.text: If you have an aversion to that word, we can call it something else. It's a simple collection of your blood, saliva, sweat, and any waste products you might produce. Remember, this is a medical exam. We must be thorough.

responses.text: Sexually dimorphic?
Um, I hope you don't need a demonstration.
The rest of my species is extinct. Does this really matter?

32.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
32.text: It pertains to the reproduction of your species. Some races are sexually dimorphic, and it would be helpful to know if yours is one of them.

responses.text: Fine. What is it?

33.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
33.text: There are some things I can't tell from an examination of a single member of a species, and this is one of them.

responses.text: I remember this. I'm male.
I remember this. I'm female.
I remember this... but it's complicated.
I don't think my species has sexes.
I'm sorry, but I have no idea.

34.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
34.text: Differences in physiology between sexes, if your species has multiple. This may be tricky for you to answer, if you truly remember nothing about your race. But if you know, it would be useful to make a note of your individual sex.

responses.text: I remember this. I'm male.
I remember this. I'm female.
I remember this... but it's complicated.
I don't think my species has sexes.
I'm sorry, but I have no idea.

35.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
35.text: Unless your species reproduces asexually, that seems unlikely. I'm asking about the possibility of your species having different sexual characteristics between individuals. This may be tricky for you to answer, if you truly remember nothing about your race. But if you know, it would be useful to make a note of your individual sex.

responses.text: I remember this. I'm male.
I remember this. I'm female.
I remember this... but it's complicated.
I don't think my species has sexes.
I'm sorry, but I have no idea.

36.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
36.text: It may, if we ever encounter another individual from your species. You may not have been the only one to be saved. Anyway, I'm asking about the possibility of your species having different sexual characteristics between individuals. This may be tricky for you to answer, if you truly remember nothing about your race. But if you know, it would be useful to make a note of your individual sex.

37.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
37.text: So you do remember. Your amnesia appears to be selective in some ways... but I'll leave that to Dr. Valken to investigate further. For now, I'll make a note that you are a male individual of your species.

38.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
38.text: So you do remember. Your amnesia appears to be selective in some ways... but I'll leave that to Dr. Valken to investigate further. For now, I'll make a note that you are a female individual of your species.

39.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
39.text: So you do remember. Your amnesia appears to be selective in some ways... but I'll leave that to Dr. Valken to investigate further. For now, I'll make a note that your individual sex is not assigned to any particular category.

40.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
40.text: So you do remember. Your amnesia appears to be selective in some ways... but I'll leave that to Dr. Valken to investigate further. For now, I'll make a note that your species is not sexually distinct. Unusual, as far as sentient species go, but not unknown.

41.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
41.text: That's fine. Unless we meet other individuals from your species, it probably won't matter.

responses.text: That's a relief to hear.
You'll tell Gleaming Shoal that?
Well, I knew I wasn't dangerous.

42.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
42.text: Continuing with the exam... Your external physiology appears unlikely to be accidentally damaging to others. No spikes, quills, toxic secretions, or serrated scales. I would recommend further observation to be safe, although full quarantine conditions are likely unnecessary.

responses.text: That'll tell you if I'm carrying any deadly diseases?
That was fast.
What do the results say?

43.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
43.text: We're not quite finished yet. I still need to analyze the results from your biological samples. It looks like the computer's finished running the basic suite of tests.

responses.text: That'll tell you if I'm carrying any deadly diseases?
That was fast.
What do the results say?

44.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
44.text: Everything will go into the official report, which I'll send to him. However, we're not quite finished yet. I still need to analyze the results from your biological samples. It looks like the computer's finished running the basic suite of tests.

45.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
45.text: It should flag any known pathogens, and any chemical structures that could cause harm to any of the species currently on board the station.

46.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
46.text: The basic suite isn't exhaustive. Hence the modifier. I'll run a more thorough set of tests while you're undergoing Dr. Valken's examination.

responses.text: What are Shapeshifters?

47.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
47.text: Let me see... Hmm. It looks like your blood contains a chemical compound that is toxic to Shapeshifters.

responses.text: Uh-oh. What can I do?
I won't let anyone ingest my blood. Problem solved.

48.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
48.text: One of the species living on the station. They don't have a large population here, and your blood is only toxic to them if ingested, but it's possible that Gleaming Shoal may use this as a reason to keep you in quarantine.

responses.text: I'll be very careful.
Hopefully Gleaming Shoal will see reason.

49.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
49.text: Personally, I don't see this as a problem. There are species on the station who can't even make physical contact with one another without breaking out into severe rashes, and they are still allowed to walk freely, as long as they are careful.

responses.text: I'll be very careful.
Hopefully Gleaming Shoal will see reason.

50.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
50.text: It does seem like an easy hazard to avoid. Personally, I don't see this as a problem. There are species on the station who can't even make physical contact with one another without breaking out into severe rashes, and they are still allowed to walk freely, as long as they are careful.

responses.text: Thanks.
I hope you're right.

51.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
51.text: I'll include my professional opinion in the report I send to Gleaming Shoal. As long as Dr. Valken's psychological profile corroborates that you are responsible enough to prevent any Shapeshifters from... ingesting your blood, you have a good chance of getting Gleaming Shoal to see things your way.

responses.text: Sounds like you don't care for him.
Well, I appreciate it anyways.

52.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
52.text: I'm simply doing my job. I would never submit a falsified report, not even to Gleaming Shoal.

responses.text: Thanks.
I'll move on to Dr. Valken's exam, then.

53.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
53.text: I'm finished with my exam now. I'd like to perform a more exhaustive one sometime in the future, but you seem anxious to press on. I'll send the results to Gleaming Shoal. Here's a paper copy for you.

responses.text: I see. I'd better get to his exam.

54.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
54.text: I don't know him well enough to form a strong opinion, but I have colleagues who have run afoul of him in the past. Dr. Valken might have more information for you on that matter.

responses.text: END

55.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
55.text: You should proceed to Dr. Valken's exam. He's over there, so approach him whenever you're ready to begin the exam. I'll be here a little longer if you still have questions.

responses.text: END

56.speaker: Dr. Talvine Mesmer-Quiverly
56.text: He's over there, so approach him whenever you're ready to begin the exam. I'll be here a little longer if you still have questions.
